sen.j: 山号 鳥形山
sen.e: Sango (literally, "mountain name", which is the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple): Mt. Torigata
Sango (literally "mountain name", this is a title prefixed to the name of Buddhist temples): Torigatazan

sen.j: 宗派 真言宗豊山派
sen.e: Religious school: Shingo sect Buzan school
Religious school: Buzan school of Shingon Buddhism

sen.j: 本尊 釈迦如来（飛鳥大仏、重要文化財）
sen.e: The principal image: Shaka Nyorai (Buddha Shakamuni) - or Asuka-daibutsu, national important cultural property
Principal image: Shaka Nyorai (the Japanese name for Shakyamuni), also known as the Great Buddha of Asuka, a designated Important Cultural Property
Principal image: Shaka Nyorai (the Japanese name for Shakyamuni), also known as the Great Buddha of Asuka, a designated Important Cultural Property

sen.j: 創建年 6世紀末頃
sen.e: Building year: around the end of the sixth century
Established: around the end of the sixth century

sen.j: 開基 蘇我馬子
sen.e: Founder: SOGA no Umako

sen.j: 正式名 鳥形山 安居院（現在の公称）
sen.e: Official name: Mt. Torigata Angoin (at present)
Official name: Torigatazan Angoin (at present)

sen.j: 別称 法興寺、元興寺（共に旧法号）
sen.e: Other names: Hoko-ji Temple, Gango-ji Temple (both of them are old names)
Other names: Hoko-ji Temple, Gango-ji Temple (both former names)

sen.j: 札所等 新西国三十三箇所9番
sen.e: Fudasho (temple where amulets are collected): the ninth temple of new 33 Saigoku Kannon Pilgrimage
Fudasho (temple on a pilgrimage route): ninth of the thirty-three temples of the New Kansai Kannon Pilgrimage

sen.cmt: 札所は、単に「巡礼路上にあるお寺」というより、「お守り札を納めたり貰ったりするお寺」という点に意義があると思います。

sen.j: 文化財 銅造釈迦如来坐像（重要文化財）
sen.e: Cultural property: The bronze sitting statue of Shaka Nyorai (national important cultural property)
Cultural property: bronze sitting statue of the Buddha (Important Cultural Property)
Cultural property: bronze sitting statue of the Buddha (Important Cultural Property)

sen.j: 飛鳥寺（あすかでら）は奈良県高市郡明日香村にある寺院である。
sen.e: Asuka-dera Temple is a temple located in Asuka Village, Takaichi District, Nara Prefecture.
Asuka-dera Temple is a temple located in Asuka Village, Takaichi District, Nara Prefecture.
Asuka-dera Temple is a temple located in Asuka Village, Takaichi District, Nara Prefecture.

sen.j: 蘇我氏の氏寺で、日本最古の本格的寺院でもある法興寺（仏法が興った寺という意味）の後身である。
sen.e: It was Uji-dera Temple (temple built for praying clan's glory) and a transformation of Hoko-ji Temple (its name means a temple where the teachings of Buddhism become prosperous) which was the oldest orthodox temple in Japan.
It's predecessor was Hoko-ji Temple, the clan temple (ujidera) of the Soga Clan and the first proper temple in Japan (Hoko-ji means 'the temple where Buddhism flourished').
It's predecessor was Hoko-ji Temple, the clan temple (ujidera) of the Soga Clan and the first proper temple in Japan (Hoko-ji means 'the temple where Buddhism flourished').

sen.j: この寺にはいくつもの呼び名がある。
sen.e: It has many names.
It is known by several different names.
It is known by several different names.

sen.j: すなわち蘇我馬子が建立した寺院の法号は「法興寺」または「元興寺」（がんごうじ）であり、法興寺中金堂跡に現在建つ小寺院の公称は「安居院」（あんごいん）だが「飛鳥寺」の呼称は江戸時代の紀行文などにも見え、「飛鳥寺式伽藍配置」など学術用語にも使われている。
sen.e: That is to say, the name of the temple which SOGA no Umako built was Hoko-ji Temple or Gango-ji Temple, and the official name of the small temple now built at the site of Hoko-ji Temple's Chukon-do Hall (middle golden hall) is 'Angoin'; However, the name 'Asuka-dere Temple' is seen on travel notes in the Edo period, and the name is also included in various technical terms, for example 'Asuka-dera-style temple layout'.

That is to say, the name of the temple built by SOGA no Umako was Hoko-ji Temple or Gango-ji Temple, and the official name of the small temple now standing on the site of Hoko-ji Temple's Chukondo (Middle Hall) is 'Angoin'; however, the name 'Asuka-dera Temple' appears in travel notes from the Edo period, and is also included in various technical terms, for example 'Asuka-dera-style temple layout'.

That is to say, the name of the temple built by SOGA no Umako was Hoko-ji Temple or Gango-ji Temple, and the official name of the small temple now standing on the site of Hoko-ji Temple's Chukondo (Middle Hall) is 'Angoin'; however, the name 'Asuka-dera Temple' appears in travel notes from the Edo period, and is also included in various technical terms, for example 'Asuka-dera-style temple layout'.

sen.j: 本項では馬子が建立した寺院とその法灯を継いで現存する寺院とを包括して、「飛鳥寺」と呼称することとする。
sen.e: In this paragraph, 'Asuka-dera Temple' is used for calling comprehensively both the temple Umako built and the present temple which succeeded its tradition.
In this article, 'Asuka-dera Temple' is used for both the temple built by Umako and the present temple which succeeded its tradition.
In this article, 'Asuka-dera Temple' is used for both the temple built by Umako and the present temple which succeeded its tradition.

sen.j: 安居院は真言宗豊山派に属する。
sen.e: Angoin belongs to Shingo sect Buzan school.
Angoin belongs to the Buzan school of Shingon Buddhism.
Angoin belongs to the Buzan school of Shingon Buddhism.

sen.j: 本尊は「飛鳥大仏」と通称される釈迦如来、開基（創立者）は馬子である。
sen.e: The principal image is Shaka Nyorai known as 'Asuka-daibutsu' and the temple was founded by Umako.
The principal image is of the Buddha, Shakyamuni, and is known as 'Asuka-daibutsu' or Great Buddha of Asuka; the temple was founded by Umako.
The principal image is of the Buddha, Shakyamuni, and is known as 'Asuka-daibutsu' or Great Buddha of Asuka; the temple was founded by Umako.

sen.j: 山号を鳥形山（とりがたやま）と称するが古代の寺院には山号はなく、後になって付けられた山号である。
sen.e: Its Sango is Mt. Torigata, but the ancient Asuka-dere Temple did not have Sango, so it was named in a later period.
Its 'sango' is Torigatazan, but since the ancient Asuka-dera Temple did not have a 'sango', this is a later addition.
Its 'sango' is Torigatazan, but since the ancient Asuka-dera Temple did not have a 'sango', this is a later addition.

sen.j: なお「鳥形山」は寺の北東、飛鳥坐神社（あすかにいますじんじゃ）のある山を指す。
sen.e: 'Mt. Torigata' is the name of a mountain, where Asukaniimasu-jinja Shrine resides and it is located northeast of the temple.
Torigatazan' is the name of a mountain to the northeast of the temple where Asukaniimasu-jinja Shrine is located.
Torigatazan' is the name of a mountain to the northeast of the temple where Asukaniimasu-jinja Shrine is located.

sen.j: 現在の飛鳥寺の前身である法興寺は蘇我氏の氏寺として6世紀末から7世紀初頭にかけて造営されたもので、明日香村豊浦の豊浦寺（尼寺。現在の向原寺がその後身）と並び日本最古の本格的仏教寺院である。
sen.e: Hoko-ji Temple, which is a predecessor of present Asuka-dera Temple, was built from the late sixth century to the early seventh century as Uji-dera Temple of the Soga clan and is the oldest true Buddhist temple along with Toyura-dera Temple (a nunnery, predecessor of Kogen-ji Temple) in Toyura, Asuka Village.

Hoko-ji Temple, the predecessor of the present Asuka-dera Temple, was built from the late sixth century to the early seventh century as the clan temple of the Soga Clan and, along with Toyura-dera Temple (a nunnery and predecessor of Kogen-ji Temple) in Toyura, Asuka Village, is the first true Buddhist temple in Japan.

Hoko-ji Temple, the predecessor of the present Asuka-dera Temple, was built from the late sixth century to the early seventh century as the clan temple of the Soga Clan and, along with Toyura-dera Temple (a nunnery and predecessor of Kogen-ji Temple) in Toyura, Asuka Village, is the first true Buddhist temple in Japan.

sen.j: 『日本書紀』によると、法興寺は用明天皇2年（587年）に蘇我馬子が建立を発願したものである。
sen.e: According to "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), SOGA no Umako made up his mind to build Hoko-ji Temple in 587.
According to the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), SOGA no Umako decided to build Hoko-ji Temple in 587.
According to the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), SOGA no Umako decided to build Hoko-ji Temple in 587.

sen.j: 馬子は排仏派の物部守屋との戦いに際し、この戦いに勝利したら仏寺を建立することを誓った。
sen.e: He is said to have sworn to build a temple for a victory over the anti-Buddhist faction, lead by MONONOBE no Moriya.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: He is said to have sworn to build a temple if he was victorious over the anti-Buddhist faction, led by MONONOBE no Moriya.
He is said to have sworn to build a temple if he was victorious over the anti-Buddhist faction, led by MONONOBE no Moriya.

sen.j: そして無事に勝利したので、飛鳥の真神原（まかみのはら）の地に寺を建てることにしたという。
sen.e: SOGA no Umako won the battle, so he decided to build the temple in Makaminohara, Asuka.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: SOGA no Umako won the battle, so he decided to build the temple in Makaminohara, Asuka.
SOGA no Umako won the battle, so he decided to build the temple in Makaminohara, Asuka.

sen.j: 一方、天平19年（747年）成立の『元興寺縁起』には発願の年は『書紀』と同じながら内容の異なる記載がある。
sen.e: On the other hand, "The Origin of Gango-ji Temple" written in 747, has a different description although the year the temple was built is the same as "Nihonshoki".
The "Gangoji-engi" (Origin of Gango-ji Temple), written in 747, while giving the same year, differs from the "Nihonshoki" in the details.
The "Gangoji-engi" (Origin of Gango-ji Temple), written in 747, while giving the same year, differs from the "Nihonshoki" in the details.

sen.j: 『縁起』によると丁未年（用明天皇2年、587年）、「百済の客」が当時の日本には尼寺しかなかったので法師寺を作るべきであることを上申し、用明天皇が後の推古天皇と聖徳太子に命じて寺を建てるべき土地を検討させたという。
sen.e: "The Origin of Gango-ji Temple" said that in 587, 'A visitor from Baekje' offered a counsel to build a temple for male Buddhist priests because there were only nunneries at that time in Japan, then Emperor Yomei ordered later Emperor Suiko and Prince Shotoku to investigate a place for the temple.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: According to the "Gangoji-engi", in 587, 'a visitor from Baekje' offered counsel on building a temple for male Buddhist priests because there were only nunneries at that time in Japan, then Emperor Yomei ordered the later Empress Suiko and Prince Shotoku to seek out a place for the temple.

According to the "Gangoji-engi", in 587, 'a visitor from Baekje' offered counsel on building a temple for male Buddhist priests because there were only nunneries at that time in Japan, then Emperor Yomei ordered the later Empress Suiko and Prince Shotoku to seek out a place for the temple.

sen.j: （当時の日本には百済に留学した善信尼などの尼はいたが、日本人の正式の男僧はいなかったと見られる。）
sen.e: (At that time in Japan, there seemed to have been no official male Buddhist priests although there were nuns such as Zenshin-ni who went Baekje to study.)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: (At that time in Japan, there seem to have been no official male Buddhist priests although there were nuns, such as Zenshin-ni who went to Baekje to study.)
(At that time in Japan, there seem to have been no official male Buddhist priests although there were nuns, such as Zenshin-ni who went to Baekje to study.)

sen.j: 『書紀』によれば翌崇峻天皇元年（588年）、百済から僧と技術者が派遣され飛鳥の真神原（まかみのはら）の地にあった飛鳥衣縫造祖樹葉（あすかきぬぬいのみやつこおやこのは）の邸宅を壊して法興寺の造営が始められた。
sen.e: "Nihonshoki" said that construction of Hoko-ji Temple began with coming of Buddhist priests and technicians from Baekje and destroying Asukakinunui no miyatsuko oyakonoha's residence in Makaminohara, Asuka in 588.

The "Nihonshoki" states that construction of Hoko-ji Temple began in 588, with the dispatch of Buddhist priests and craftsmen from Baekje and the demolition of the residence of Konoha, ancestor of the Asuka no Kinunui no Miyatsuko, in Makaminohara, Asuka.

The "Nihonshoki" states that construction of Hoko-ji Temple began in 588, with the dispatch of Buddhist priests and craftsmen from Baekje and the demolition of the residence of Konoha, ancestor of the Asuka no Kinunui no Miyatsuko, in Makaminohara, Asuka.

sen.j: 『書紀』の崇峻天皇5年（592年）の条には「大法興寺の仏堂と歩廊とを起（た）つ」とあり、整地工事や木材の調達が終わって本格的な造営が始まったのはこの年からとする説もある。
sen.e: There is a mention in the article of 592 in "Nihonshoki" saying "Grand Hoko-ji Temple's Buddha statue hall and corridor began construction", so in a theory, this year seemed the first year of full-scale construction after leveling the ground and procuring lumber.

The "Nihonshoki" entry for 592 mentions that "construction began on Grand Hoko-ji Temple's Buddha statue hall and corridor", so it is possible that this was the first year of full-scale construction after ground leveling and procuring lumber.

The "Nihonshoki" entry for 592 mentions that "construction began on Grand Hoko-ji Temple's Buddha statue hall and corridor", so it is possible that this was the first year of full-scale construction after ground leveling and procuring lumber.

sen.j: 『書紀』の推古天皇元年1月15日 (旧暦)（593年2月21日）の条には「法興寺の刹柱（塔の心柱）の礎の中に仏舎利を置く」との記事があり、翌日の1月16日 (旧暦)（2月22日）に「刹柱を建てた」とある。
sen.e: And there are also mentions in the article of February 21, 593 in "Nihonshoki", saying 'Buddha's bones are put in the foundation of a central pillar of Hoko-ji Temple's pagoda and 'the central pillar was built' on the next day (the 22nd).

The "Nihonshoki" entry for February 21, 593, also reports that "the Buddha's bones are put in the foundations of the central pillar of Hoko-ji Temple's pagoda" and, the following day (the 22nd), that "the central pillar was raised".

The "Nihonshoki" entry for February 21, 593, also reports that "the Buddha's bones are put in the foundations of the central pillar of Hoko-ji Temple's pagoda" and, the following day (the 22nd), that "the central pillar was raised".

sen.j: なお昭和32年（1957年）の発掘調査の結果、塔跡の地下に埋まっていた心礎（塔の心柱の礎石）に舎利容器が埋納されていたことが確認されている。
sen.e: In this connection, an excavation for research in 1957 confirmed a vessel of Buddha's bones in a foundation stone of the central pillar buried in the ground of the pagoda site.
In 1957, excavations at the site of the pagoda confirmed a vessel containing the Buddha's bones had been buried under the foundation stone of the central pillar.
In 1957, excavations at the site of the pagoda confirmed a vessel containing the Buddha's bones had been buried under the foundation stone of the central pillar.

sen.j: 『書紀』の推古天皇4年（596年）11月条に「法興寺を造り竟（おわ）りぬ」との記事がある。
sen.e: The article of November, 596 in "Nihonshoki" said 'Hoko-ji Temple was completed'.
The "Nihonshoki" article for November, 596, states that "Hoko-ji Temple was completed".
The "Nihonshoki" article for November, 596, states that "Hoko-ji Temple was completed".

sen.j: しかし後述のように法興寺本尊の釈迦三尊像が完成したのはそれから少なくとも9年後のことであり寺は完成したが、9年間は本尊が存在しなかったということになってしまう。
sen.e: However, as below, the principal images: the statues of Shakyamuni triads were finished at least nine years later, so it means the temple did not have its principal images for nine years after it had been completed.

However, as stated below, the principal object of worship, a Shaka-sanzon, or Shakyamuni Buddha Triad, was not finished for a further nine years, meaning the temple did not have its principal images for nine years after it had been completed.

However, as stated below, the principal object of worship, a Shaka-sanzon, or Shakyamuni Buddha Triad, was not finished for a further nine years, meaning the temple did not have its principal images for nine years after it had been completed.

sen.j: この点については研究者によってさまざまな解釈があり、一説には推古天皇4年（596年）にはまず塔が完成し他の堂宇はその後順次建立されたのではないかという。
sen.e: On this point, there are many explanations depending on researchers, one theory is that the pagoda was completed first in 596, and then the other temple buildings were built one after another.
On this point, different researchers have different explanations, with one theory being that the pagoda was completed first in 596, and the other temple buildings were built in turn after that.
On this point, different researchers have different explanations, with one theory being that the pagoda was completed first in 596, and the other temple buildings were built in turn after that.

sen.j: 昭和31～32年（1956年～1957年）の発掘調査の結果によれば当初の法興寺は中心の五重塔を囲んで中金堂、東金堂、西金堂が建つ一塔三金堂式の壮大な伽藍であった。
sen.e: An excavation for research from 1956 to1957 found that original Hoko-ji Temple was a magnificent one-pagoda-and-three-golden-hall-style temple with a center five-storied pagoda surrounded by a middle golden hall, an eastern golden hall, and a western golden hall.

Excavations from 1956 to1957 found that the original Hoko-ji Temple was a magnificent one-pagoda-three-hall-style temple with a central five-storied pagoda surrounded by a middle kondo, an eastern kondo, and a western kondo.

Excavations from 1956 to1957 found that the original Hoko-ji Temple was a magnificent one-pagoda-three-hall-style temple with a central five-storied pagoda surrounded by a middle kondo, an eastern kondo, and a western kondo.

sen.j: 法興寺中金堂本尊の釈迦三尊像について『書紀』は推古天皇13年（605年）に造り始められ翌14年（606年）完成、作者は鞍作鳥（くらつくりのとり）であるという。
sen.e: In "Nihonshoki", the principal image of the middle golden hall of Hoko-ji Temple: the statues of Shakyamuni triads are said to have been started making in 605 and finished in 606 by Kuratsukurinotori.

According to the "Nihonshoki", the principal image of the middle kondo of Hoko-ji Temple, the statues of the Shakyamuni Buddha Triad are said to have been begun by Kuratsukurinotori in 605 and finished in 606.

According to the "Nihonshoki", the principal image of the middle kondo of Hoko-ji Temple, the statues of the Shakyamuni Buddha Triad are said to have been begun by Kuratsukurinotori in 605 and finished in 606.

sen.j: なお、『元興寺縁起』に引く「丈六光銘」（「一丈六尺の仏像の光背銘」の意）には乙丑年（推古天皇13年、605年）に「敬造」（謹んで造るの意）し、己巳年（609年）に「畢竟」（造り終わるの意）とある。
sen.e: Incidentally, according to "The Origin of Gango-ji Temple", there was an inscription on the halo of the sixteen-shaku (shaku= about 30.3cm) high statue, which said the statue was heartily started making in 605 and finished in 609.

Incidentally, according to "Gangoji-engi", there was an inscription on the halo of the sixteen-shaku (around 4.85m) high statue, which said the statue was "reverently begun" in 605 and finished in 609.

Incidentally, according to "Gangoji-engi", there was an inscription on the halo of the sixteen-shaku (around 4.85m) high statue, which said the statue was "reverently begun" in 605 and finished in 609.

sen.j: 大化の改新による蘇我氏宗家滅亡以後も内外の信仰を集め、天武天皇の時代には大安寺・川原寺・薬師寺と並ぶ「四大寺」の一とされて朝廷の保護を受けるようになった。
sen.e: Even after the extinction of the head family of the Soga clan by the Taika Reforms, Hoko-ji Temple was still a center of religion, and in the period of Emperor Tenmu, came to be protected by Imperial Court as the one of 'the four great temples' along with Daian-ji Temple, Kawahara-dera Temple, and Yakushi-ji Temple.

Even after the Taika Reforms led to the extinction of the Soga Clan's head family, Hoko-ji Temple remained a center of religion and, during Emperor Tenmu's reign, came under the protection of the Imperial Court as the one of the 'Four Great Temples', along with Daian-ji Temple, Kawahara-dera Temple, and Yakushi-ji Temple.

Even after the Taika Reforms led to the extinction of the Soga Clan's head family, Hoko-ji Temple remained a center of religion and, during Emperor Tenmu's reign, came under the protection of the Imperial Court as the one of the 'Four Great Temples', along with Daian-ji Temple, Kawahara-dera Temple, and Yakushi-ji Temple.

sen.j: これに関連して飛鳥寺近くの飛鳥池遺跡からは大量の富本銭が発見され、その位置づけを巡って（飛鳥寺との関係も含めて）様々な議論が行われている。
sen.e: Relating to that, many Fuhonsen coins were detected in the Asukaike Ruins near Asuka-dera Temple and various discussions on an origin of them (including a connection with Asuka-dera Temple) are held.
Relating to that, many ancient coins, known as Fuhonsen, were found in the Asukaike Ruins near Asuka-dera Temple and their origins (including a connection with Asuka-dera Temple) are hotly debated.
Relating to that, many ancient coins, known as Fuhonsen, were found in the Asukaike Ruins near Asuka-dera Temple and their origins (including a connection with Asuka-dera Temple) are hotly debated.

tit.e: After national capital transfer to Heijo
Following Transfer of Capital to Heijo
Following Transfer of Capital to Heijo

sen.j: 都が平城京へ移るとともに法興寺も現在の奈良市に移転し元興寺となったが、飛鳥の法興寺も存続し本元興寺と称された。
sen.e: With the national capital transfer to Heijo-kyo, Hoko-ji Temple was also moved to present-day Nara City and named Gango-ji Temple; however Hoko-ji Temple in Asuka continued to be there and named Moto Gango-ji Temple.

When the capital was moved to Heijo-kyo, Hoko-ji Temple was also moved to present-day Nara City and renamed Gango-ji Temple, though Hoko-ji Temple in Asuka continued to exist under the name Moto Gango-ji Temple.

When the capital was moved to Heijo-kyo, Hoko-ji Temple was also moved to present-day Nara City and renamed Gango-ji Temple, though Hoko-ji Temple in Asuka continued to exist under the name Moto Gango-ji Temple.

sen.j: 建久7年（1196年）の火災による焼失後、中世以降の衰退は著しく江戸時代には仮堂一宇を残すのみであった。
sen.e: It was destroyed by fire in 1196, and declined remarkably after the Medieval Period, so only a temporary hall remained in the Edo period.
It was destroyed by fire in 1196, and went into a drastic decline during the Middle Ages so that, in the Edo period, only a temporary hall remained.
It was destroyed by fire in 1196, and went into a drastic decline during the Middle Ages so that, in the Edo period, only a temporary hall remained.

sen.j: 江戸時代の学者・本居宣長の『菅笠日記』には、彼が明和9年（1772年）に飛鳥を訪ねた時の様子が書かれているが、当時の飛鳥寺は「門などもなく」「かりそめなる堂」に本尊釈迦如来像が安置されるのみだったという。
sen.e: In a description of a visit to Asuka in 1772 in "Sugegasa Nikki" (Sedge Hat Diary) of a scholar in the Edo period: Norinaga MOTOORI, Asuka-dera Temple was said to have 'no gate' and only the principal image: Shaka Nyorai in ' a temporary hall' at that time.

Norinaga MOTOORI, the Edo period scholar, visited Asuka-dera Temple in 1772, describing it in his diary "Sugegasa Nikki" as "having no gate" and "a temporary hall" that contained only the principal image of the Buddha.

Norinaga MOTOORI, the Edo period scholar, visited Asuka-dera Temple in 1772, describing it in his diary "Sugegasa Nikki" as "having no gate" and "a temporary hall" that contained only the principal image of the Buddha.

sen.j: 現在、参道入口に立つ「飛鳥大仏」の石碑は寛政4年（1792年）のもので当時すでに「飛鳥大仏」と呼ばれていたことがわかる。
sen.e: A stone monument referring to 'Asuka-daibutsu', which is now standing at the entrance of the approach to the temple, has existed since 1792 and shows that the statue was already called 'Asuka-daibutsu' at that time.

A stone monument referring to "Asuka-daibutsu", which now stands at the entrance of the approach to the temple, has existed since 1792 and shows that the statue was already called "Asuka-daibutsu" at that time.

A stone monument referring to "Asuka-daibutsu", which now stands at the entrance of the approach to the temple, has existed since 1792 and shows that the statue was already called "Asuka-daibutsu" at that time.

sen.j: 現・本堂は江戸末期の文政8年（1825年）に大坂の篤志家の援助で再建されたもので、創建当時の壮大な伽藍をしのぶべくもない。
sen.e: The present main hall was rebuilt in 1825 in the end of the Edo period with support by a charitable person of Osaka, but it's a mere shadow of the original magnificent temple building.
The present main hall was rebuilt in 1825 at the end of the Edo period with support from a donor in Osaka, and as such, it is hard to gain an appreciation of the magnificent original temple.
The present main hall was rebuilt in 1825 at the end of the Edo period with support from a donor in Osaka, and as such, it is hard to gain an appreciation of the magnificent original temple.

sen.j: しかし発掘調査の結果、現在の飛鳥寺本堂の建つ場所はまさしく馬子の建てた法興寺中金堂の跡地であり、本尊の釈迦如来像（飛鳥大仏）は補修が甚だしいとはいえ飛鳥時代と同じ場所に安置されていることがわかった。
sen.e: However, as a result of an excavation for research, the place where the main hall of Asuka-dera Temple is standing now was revealed to be the exact same site as the middle golden hall of Hoko-ji Temple built by Umako, and the principal image: Shaka Nyorai (or Asuk-daibutsu) was enshrined on the same position as it was in the Asuka period even though it was extremely repaired.

However, excavations have revealed that the place where Asuka-dera Temple's main hall now stands is the exact same site as the middle golden hall of Hoko-ji Temple built by Umako, and the principal image of the Buddha (or Asuka-daibutsu), although extensively repaired, is enshrined in the same position as it was in the Asuka period.

However, excavations have revealed that the place where Asuka-dera Temple's main hall now stands is the exact same site as the middle golden hall of Hoko-ji Temple built by Umako, and the principal image of the Buddha (or Asuka-daibutsu), although extensively repaired, is enshrined in the same position as it was in the Asuka period.

sen.j: 日本最古の寺院・法興寺は衰退したとはいえ、21世紀の今日までその法灯を守り続けているわけである。
sen.e: In other words, the oldest temple in Japan: Hoko-ji Temple kept maintaining its tradition until today, the 21st century although it declined.
In other words, although it has experienced a decline, Hoko-ji Temple, the oldest temple in Japan, has maintained its traditions up until today, the 21st century.
In other words, although it has experienced a decline, Hoko-ji Temple, the oldest temple in Japan, has maintained its traditions up until today, the 21st century.

sen.j: 新西国三十三箇所第9番
sen.e: The ninth temple of new 33 Saigoku Kannon Pilgrimage
The ninth temple of new 33 Saigoku Kannon Pilgrimage
The ninth temple of new 33 Saigoku Kannon Pilgrimage

sen.j: 銅造釈迦如来坐像（国の重要文化財） - 飛鳥寺（安居院）の本尊。
sen.e: The Bronze sitting statue of Shaka Nyorai (national important cultural property) - The principal image of Asuka-dera Temple (Angoin)
Bronze sitting statue of Shakyamuni (Important Cultural Property) - The principal image of Asuka-dera Temple (Angoin)
Bronze sitting statue of Shakyamuni (Important Cultural Property) - The principal image of Asuka-dera Temple (Angoin)

sen.j: 飛鳥大仏の通称で知られる。
sen.e: It is commonly known as Asuka-daibutsu.
It is commonly known as Asuka-daibutsu, or the Great Buddha of Asuka.
It is commonly known as Asuka-daibutsu, or the Great Buddha of Asuka.

sen.j: 「起源と歴史」の項で述べたとおり7世紀初頭、鞍作鳥の作とされる。
sen.e: As 'Origin and history' section mentioned, it is said to have been made by Kuratsukurinotori in the beginning of the 7th century.
As mentioned in the 'Origins and History' section, it is said to have been made by Kuratsukuri no Tori at the beginning of the 7th century.
As mentioned in the 'Origins and History' section, it is said to have been made by Kuratsukuri no Tori at the beginning of the 7th century.

sen.j: 作鳥は、法隆寺金堂本尊釈迦三尊像の作者である「司馬鞍首止利」（しばくらつくりのおびととり）と同一人物とみるのが一般的理解である。
sen.e: He is generally considered to have been the same person as Shibatukuri no obitotori who made the principal image of the golden hall of Horyu-ji Temple: the statues of Shakyamuni triads.
He is generally considered to have been the same person as Shibatukuri no Obito Tori, who made the Shakyamuni Triad that is the principal image in Horyu-ji Temple's kondo.
He is generally considered to have been the same person as Shibatukuri no Obito Tori, who made the Shakyamuni Triad that is the principal image in Horyu-ji Temple's kondo.

sen.j: 当初は法隆寺釈迦三尊像と同様の三尊形式だったはずだが両脇侍像は失われ、釈迦像も鎌倉時代の建久7年（1196年）の落雷のための火災で甚大な損害を受けており当初の部分は顔の上半分、左耳、右手の第2・3・4指に残るのみだといわれる。
sen.e: It is believed to have originally been a triad style like the statues of Shakyamuni triads of Horyu-ji Temple, however both-sides attendants were lost and the statue itself was seriously damaged by fire caused by lightning, so only its upper half of the face; left ear; index finger, middle finger, and third finger of right hand, are said to be its original parts.

It is believed to have originally been a triad like the statues of Horyu-ji Temple's Shakyamuni triad; however, both side-attendants were lost and the statue itself was seriously damaged by fire caused by lightning, so that only the upper half of the face, the left ear, and the index, middle, and third fingers of the right hand are said to be original.

It is believed to have originally been a triad like the statues of Horyu-ji Temple's Shakyamuni triad; however, both side-attendants were lost and the statue itself was seriously damaged by fire caused by lightning, so that only the upper half of the face, the left ear, and the index, middle, and third fingers of the right hand are said to be original.

sen.j: 亀裂の入った部分を粘土で埋め紙を張って墨を塗った部分などがあり、大幅な補修が加えられていることは確かである。
sen.e: There are cracked parts covered with first clay and then paper, and painted Indian ink, so certainly, it was repaired greatly.
sen.cmt: 原文の流れが悪かったため、一部修正しました。一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Cracked parts are covered with clay and then paper, and then painted with Indian ink, so it is certain that it has undergone extensive repairs.
Cracked parts are covered with clay and then paper, and then painted with Indian ink, so it is certain that it has undergone extensive repairs.

sen.j: しかし、当初部分がどの程度残存しているのか正確にはわかっていない。
sen.e: However, it is not precisely known how much of its original parts remained.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: However, it is not precisely known how much of what remains is original.
However, it is not precisely known how much of what remains is original.

sen.j: 右手の第2・3・4指については、掌の部分にほぞ差しされていることがエックス線撮影によって確認されている。
sen.e: The index finger, middle finger, and third finger of its right hand were confirmed to be mortised to the palm by X-ray.
The index finger, middle finger, and third finger of the right hand were confirmed by X-ray to be mortised to the palm.
The index finger, middle finger, and third finger of the right hand were confirmed by X-ray to be mortised to the palm.

sen.j: アーモンド形の眼の表現などは現存する他の飛鳥仏に共通する表現が見られる。
sen.e: The representation of its almond-shape eyes is common to other present Asuka-style Buddha statues.
sen.cmt: 原文の流れが悪く、「アーモンド形の眼の表現などは現存する他の飛鳥仏と共通する。」と理解しました。
sen.e: The representation of its almond-shape eyes is common to other extant Asuka-style Buddha statues.
The representation of its almond-shape eyes is common to other extant Asuka-style Buddha statues.

sen.j: 体部のほとんどが後補とみられるが胸前に紐の結び目を表す服制は古様であり、当初像の表現を踏襲している可能性がある。
sen.e: Although almost all parts of the body seems to have been repaired later, the way of representing a knot of a string on the chest uses an old style, so the way the knot is represented may replicate the original.
Although almost every part of the body seems to have been repaired at some point, the knot tying the string on the chest is done in an old style, and so is likely to replicate the original.
Although almost every part of the body seems to have been repaired at some point, the knot tying the string on the chest is done in an old style, and so is likely to replicate the original.

sen.e: Take the bus for Okadera-mae for ten minutes
Take the bus for Okadera-mae for ten minutes
